title: First Homo expansion out of Africa
desc: Earliest hominin expansions into Eurasia (~2.0–1.8 Ma).

title: Sima de los Huesos mtDNA (early Neanderthal signal)
desc: Middle Pleistocene hominins from Sima de los Huesos (~430 ka) yielded mtDNA showing early Neanderthal lineage.
harvard_refs: Meyer, M. et al. (2016) Nuclear DNA sequences from the Middle Pleistocene Sima de los Huesos hominins. Nature, 531, 504–507.

title: Emergence of early Neanderthal–Denisovan ancestry
desc: Genomic divergence between the Neanderthal and Denisovan lineages began around 400–450 ka, following earlier separation from Homo sapiens ancestors.
harvard_refs: Prüfer, K. et al. (2014) The complete genome sequence of a Neanderthal from the Altai Mountains. Nature, 505, 43–49.
Meyer, M. et al. (2012) A high-coverage genome sequence from an archaic Denisovan individual. Science, 338, 222–226.

title: Denisovan population in Altai region
desc: Denisovans inhabited southern Siberia (Altai) by at least 300 ka, leaving DNA traces later detected in modern populations of Oceania and Asia.
harvard_refs: Meyer, M. et al. (2012) A high-coverage genome sequence from an archaic Denisovan individual. Science, 338, 222–226.

title: Earliest Neanderthal genomes – Sima de los Huesos, Spain
desc: Mitochondrial DNA from ~430 ka Sima de los Huesos fossils revealed an early Neanderthal lineage, pushing back the origin of Neanderthal traits.
harvard_refs: Meyer, M. et al. (2016) Nuclear DNA sequences from the Middle Pleistocene Sima de los Huesos hominins. Nature, 531, 504–507.

title: Emergence of Homo sapiens in Africa
desc: Fossils from Omo Kibish (~195 ka) and Herto (~160 ka) in Ethiopia represent early anatomically modern humans; genetic evidence suggests African population structure before Out-of-Africa expansion.
harvard_refs: White, T.D. et al. (2003) Pleistocene Homo sapiens from Middle Awash, Ethiopia. Nature, 423, 742–747.
Scerri, E.M.L. et al. (2018) Did our species evolve in subdivided populations across Africa? Trends in Ecology & Evolution, 33, 582–594.

title: Neanderthal admixture with modern humans
desc: Ancient DNA revealed gene flow from Neanderthals into non-African modern humans, occurring soon after the Out-of-Africa expansion (~50–60 ka).
harvard_refs: Green, R.E. et al. (2010) A draft sequence of the Neandertal genome. Nature, 464, 711–716.

title: Denisovan introgression into East and Southeast Asia
desc: Genetic data show introgression from Denisovans into ancestors of present-day East and Southeast Asians, and especially Papuans and Aboriginal Australians.
harvard_refs: Reich, D. et al. (2011) Denisova admixture and the genetic history of Melanesia. Nature, 468, 1053–1060.
Browning, S.R. et al. (2018) Analysis of human sequence data reveals two pulses of Denisovan admixture. Cell, 173, 53–61.

title: Postglacial diversification of Eurasian populations
desc: Genomes from Upper Palaeolithic and Mesolithic Europe show population turnovers and structure leading to present-day West Eurasian ancestry.
harvard_refs: Lazaridis, I. et al. (2014) Ancient human genomes suggest three ancestral populations for present-day Europeans. Nature, 513, 409–413.
Fu, Q. et al. (2016) The genetic history of Ice Age Europe. Nature, 534, 200–205.
